captions.text: [CAR ENGINE]

Hot hatches and UK roads
are like roast beef and
horseradish sauce--

so perfect in each other's
company, you wonder if they

weren't designed purely
for each other.

Now Ford is a master of turning
a shopping trolley

into something genuinely
fast and exciting.

So the new Focus ST, now with
just four cylinders, is a good

reason to see what's happening
on Planet Hatchback.

Up against the Ford are the
exceptional Renaultsport

Megane and the very
potent Astra VXR.
Winner takes all.

Try not to drive them
like a nutter.

But that's actually
not possible in
one of these, right?
[CAR ENGINE]

The Astra VXR is one of
the least subtle cars
on sale in the UK.

Normally, Vauxhall's efforts
in the VXR department are

uncouth, and I say, not
very good on the road.

But this little GTC-based car
is, I think, quite funky.
[CAR ENGINE]
It's just quite unruly.
OK.

How have we got this performance
in this package?

We've got a front-wheel drive
car on the other two, and

we've got a shedload of
power and torque,
but it's less subtle.

Delivery is more difficult
in this car.
There's more lag.

So you have to kind of
anticipate what's going on.

Now some people might find
that a pain in the ass.

I could at times, but actually
it makes for
quite an amusing device.

You can sort of left foot brake
it and then just wind

the throttle and then wait
for it to come in.

On a smooth A-road, it feels
really quite good.

On a bumpy B-road, it's
a bit oversprung.
It's a bit underdamped.

And that's before you hit the
VXR button, which makes things

more aggressive in terms of
throttle and even more

aggressive in terms
of spring rate.

Or they use the damper,
don't they?

Then it becomes very
unruly indeed.
[CAR ENGINE]

There's much to love and
celebrate about this car,

though, because it's an honest
in-your-face hot hatch.

If you like your hair combed
in 19 different directions

with a product, and the priority
when buying jeans is

whether you can show the top two
inches of your ass crevice

to the world, then you're going
to love the way this
thing looks.
It's full-on.

The basic shape is
great as well.

These seats are excellent,
I have to say.

It's a theme with
all three cars.

They've really tried
with the cabin.
They're fantastic.
They're massive, comfortable.

They just look sporty,
don't they?
The rest of the cabin, hmm.
Yes.

It's going to take me a long,
long time to get used to what
these buttons do.

They're so small, you spend
half your time looking at
what's going on.
It's just in your face.
It's very honest about that.

So if you want it, the VXR
kind of offers it.

Anyway, this may have a
similarly stiff chassis to the

VXR, but after that, the
similarities kind of end.

Renaultsport are very good
at making hot hatchbacks.

And this thing is
no exception.

The first time you get in this
Megane, you could be mistaken

for thinking after the other
two, well, the cabin's
completely bare.

It feels like it should be worth
about half the money.

And even when you drive it
slowly, you might think,
what's all the fuss about?

But the moment you get going in
it, you realize that this

has had some proper attention
lavished on it.
It is superb.

Dif means it's got more traction
in the wet here.

And the faster you drive it, the
harder you drive it, the
more it brings back to you.

The gear shift has
a shorter throw.
The steering is fast.
The whole car comes alive.

And I've said this before, but
that RS moniker kind of fits

the car the way it does
those Porsche models.

They just feel very,
very special.

It's quite harsh, but
interestingly, the faster you

go, the more controlled
it feels.

The complete opposite of the
VXR, which, if you really

push, starts to lose it a
bit and get a bit baggy.
I do love these things.
The motor--

actually, the motor is starting
to feel a little bit

tired now, because the Ford,
as you'll find, that has a
great engine.

And that VXR, it's got
more punch than this.

And this, actually, is
still quite laggy.

I just love the way that on a
damp day, you can cover ground
so quickly in these things.

Part of the reason why the car
gives you so much confidence

in these damp conditions out
here is the steering.

At very low speed,
it seems to have
absolutely no feel at all.

But when you get going, it's
just right, I think.
It's just right.
Special car, this.
Special car.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now in some respects, it's a bit
unfair taking a Focus ST

and putting it against the
Megane Renaultsport and also a

VXR, because that's an RS's
job, really, isn't it?

So we're perhaps a bit too far
down the Ford food chain.

But this thing acquits itself
very, very well,
even in this company.
[CAR ENGINE]

There is much to appreciate
in this car.

I will start with the engine,
which has much more response
than the other two.
It doesn't have much lag.

There's a little bit, but it
just feels very elastic,

giving you whatever you want
when you demand it.

So that means that on the road,
it feels just as quick
as the other two.

Perhaps in terms of immediate
response, it feels quicker.
The steering--

to start with, it feels
just too quick.

But I quite like the fact that
you work without turning your

arms over the wheel
and grabbing
extra armfuls of lock.
The chassis.

Softer, more subtle, and it
works with a UK road just
better than the other two.

As an everyday car, this
is a nicer place to be.
The seats--
exceptional.
With Recaro logos everywhere.

I'm not too old to
enjoy those.
Yes, it's a great road car.

I sort of miss the fact that
you can't get a three-door,

and it has to be a five-door,
but you get used
to that quite quickly.

It's a funky looking
car, isn't it?
The cabin--

now, some people that have
driven this car this week

think it's just a bit too
complicated and chavved up.

Me, well, some people like lots
of complication and cool
stuff going on.
It is a bit too much.

This Sony hi-fi can't
always work out.

But the rest of it, it just
feels like Ford's tried to

give you a lot of stuff
for your money.

And in the most part,
it works.
[CAR ENGINE]

Can a hot hatch really
have electric power
steering and work?

OK, it is kind of lacking any
kind of feel, and what Ford

has done is given it a load of
resistance just off center.

So the car gives you initial
resistance just off center
that you feel as weight.

The problem is, it's quite
aggressive self-centering back
the other way.

So if I let go of the wheel,
the car straightens
immediately.
That is not very realistic.

But you quickly build a rhythm
with the car where you just

sort of steer it quite lightly,
and you don't need to

use too much lock to get around
quite tight bends.

It's a different
way of driving.

It doesn't feel like a young,
small, angry, hot hatchback.

It feels quite mature
and grown up.

It feels like a really nice car
to live with year round.
[CAR ENGINE]

So the Ford noses ahead on the
road, but what happens when

you send them around a tight,
rather wet, little circuit?
[CAR ENGINE]
Okay.
Llandow Circuit.
Wicked little place.
[CAR ENGINE]
In the Focus.

I've got the traction
on at the moment.

It's so slippery,
it's definitely
worth keeping it on.
[CAR ENGINE]

The fact that it's a bit
softer than the others
probably helps it quite a lot.
[CAR ENGINE]

Do like the chassis bounce
in this car.

It's just got a slightly mobile
rear end on it, which

means that if you peered away
from the throttle a bit, it

would just help the
car into the turn.
It's not too lairy.
It's not dangerous.

It's just what I'd
call mobile.
Very tight little places.

It's almost like a
go-kart track.
[CAR ENGINE]

In this Ford, in these
conditions I have to say, very
impressive indeed.
System's working really well.
I've got some turn in.

I haven't got too
much understeer.

Compared to the Audi RS3 the
other week, I had monstrous
understeer.
I haven't with this.
[CAR ENGINE]

Real advantage of this sort of
weather, being front wheel

drive, you just lean
on the throttle.
[CAR ENGINE]

In these conditions, I
really like this car.

In fact, I just like
it full stop.
It's nice.
It's supple.
Its engine, listen to it.
250 horsepower.
Makes a great noise.

There's clearly some sort of
intake resonator thing going

on, but it's not
too artificial,
and it's just cool.
It is just cool.

I love hatchbacks in this
sort of weather.

Systems have come a long
way, haven't they?

I'm just leaning on
this thing now.

Where the rain's coming in hard,
you just stay wide open.
[CAR ENGINE]
Cracking little car.

Balance, good brakes, they're
not getting too much fade,

good wet weather grip,
good traction.

Just get the feeling this has
been developed by people that
like driving.
You know what?
That's a good thing.
[CAR ENGINE]

The Megane Renaultsport
in its preferred
element, the circuit.

Let's drop that steering
wheel down a bit.
What's it like here, then?
Feels pokey.

Immediately, I like the
size of the car.
I like the way that it feels.
I like the way that it steers.

Again, like the others, they've
got balance, traction.
There's a locker in this.
You can feel it.
Yes.
[CAR ENGINE]
We'll leave it in second.
Bounce over a couple of curbs.

Again, the rear axle's quite
mobile, wants to get us--
wants to help us round.
[CAR ENGINE]
Oh yes.
Oh yes.

Feels more agile than
the others.
Brakes are good.
All the controls are good.

Like the steering column's come
back to me a little bit.
OK.

We're being held back a bit by
the traction control there, so
it's going off.

Let's try a lap without
the traction on, OK?

In the others I left it on
because it wasn't getting in

the way, but in this, I
think it is, slightly.
[CAR ENGINE]

Front-wheel drive cars are just
so flipping competent
these days.
That feels good.

That just feels bloody
marvelous.
[CAR ENGINE]

What a wicked bit
of kit this is.
It just pendulums a bit.
Cracking thing.
Cracking, cracking thing.

I'm so glad Renault still makes
cars like this, because

it's got some difficulties in
other areas, but it's fabby.
Absolutely fabby.
[CAR ENGINE]

This is a slightly unfair test
for the Astra, because it's

got extra power over the others,
but this wet whether

is going to negate
some of that.

Even so, let's see
how it gets on.

We're on the back, straight,
third gear, fourth gear, over
100 miles an hour.
Braking hard.
Get third.
Pedal's not ideal.
Quick through the chicane.

Fast direction change, and
the car takes it well.

I have to say, the car
takes it well.
Now this back straight.

Turn it in early, open the taps
up, dif and electronics

working really quite well
in these conditions.

This is so much better than the
last generation of these
cars that I drove.

I braked a bit early there, so
this time we can carry a bit
more speed, I think.

We'll try one more quick
one through there.
Car's flat, steering's quick.

It doesn't have the suppleness
of the Ford, and it doesn't

have the immediacy of the Ford's
throttle response.

But this really is so much
better than I expected.

These VXR products can be quite
disappointing, and I

think this is quite a
nice car, actually.
Certainly fast.

I'm not finding the pedal
position very
easy, have to say.

But on a track like this in
these conditions, that VXR
mode is best left well alone.

Hatchbacks are just
cool, aren't they?

Through these curby sections,
good direction changes.

You can just get that dif
hooked up, and it goes.
This quicker right hand.

Again, there's mobility
to the rear axle.

Makes it fun, makes
it adjustable.
Bit of oversteer there.
I like this.
Well done, Vauxhall.
Well bloody done.
Woo hoo!
Oh, yeah.

This is a good feeling, to
drive a Vauxhall product
that's this much fun.
[CAR ENGINE]

Now, I make no apologies for
this being a deliberately and

unashamedly UK-based test,
because these cars are perfect

for our roads and our
weather conditions.

They are three very, very
good cars, actually.

So a general harumph
all around.

This is a very, very
talented class.

Sadly, a car has to
come last, though.
And that is the Vauxhall.

Strangely, it is the biggest
surprise of the test for me,

because I expected it
to be dreadful.

But just by a few degrees in
every department, it is the
weakest car here.

And I think at 27,000 pounds,
it's quite expensive for what

it offers, although it
is very, very fast.

It's miles better than
the last VXR I drove.
So well done, Vauxhall.

Picking a winner is
more difficult.

I'm going to give
you two winners.

If you want to do some track
date, and you want the

ultimate sharp front-wheel drive
experience, you have to
go for the Megane.
It's just exceptional.

But if I was going to live with
a hot hatch for the next

year, it would have to be a
Focus ST. It's lovely on the

road and surprisingly capable
on the track, as well.
One last note, though.

This Focus ST is getting
quite expensive.

It's 28,000 pounds as tested
with a few extras.

So the M135i is shaking things
up a bit here, isn't it?

That car, at just under
30,000 pounds, puts
immense pressure on these.

But there's something about
capable, well-packaged

front-wheel drive performance
that I'll always love.
Yeah.
Good cars.

title: Ford Focus ST Hot Hatchback Showdown - /CHRIS HARRIS ON CARS
